item.title: India Ink: Police Arrest 3 in Gang Rape of American
item.description: On Thursday morning Himachal Pradesh Police arrested the men and seized the vehicle in which the alleged crime was committed.
item.dc:creator: By MALAVIKA VYAWAHARE and VISHNU VARMA
item.media:description: Police keeping a check on vehicles in Manali, Himachal Pradesh, on Tuesday.

item.title: North and South Korea Agree to Dialogue
item.description: South Korea welcomed a surprise overture from the North, suggesting a possible thaw in relations that have been deeply hostile in recent months.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: IHT Quick Read: June 6
item.description: Obama administration carrying out domestic surveillance program; the earliest fossil primate ever found; a sharply self-critical report from the I.M.F.; revelations at the Venice Biennale ; and Nadal and Djokovic will meet in the French Open semifinal on Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: By THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE
item.media:credit: Newsha Tavakolian for The New York Times
item.media:description: Few in Qum, a home to influential clerics, speak openly against the Iranian government.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Charges Against Chinese Rights Activist Said to Be Reduced
item.description: Liu Ping, a rights activist, has had her charges lessened from subversion to “illegal assembly,” her daughter and lawyer said; but could still face a multi-year jail term if convicted.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIISTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Liu Ping, a rights activist whose sentence was changed from subversion to "illegal assembly," her daughter said.

item.title: U.S. Is Secretly Collecting Records of Verizon Calls
item.description: A highly classified court order disclosed on Wednesday night directs a Verizon Communications subsidiary to turn over to the National Security Agency logs of calls on a daily basis.
item.dc:creator: By CHARLIE SAVAGE and EDWARD WYATT

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Iraq: 14 Travelers Are Killed by Gunmen
item.description: Gunmen killed 14 people in Nukhaib, a police official said. An official in Karbala, where several of the dead were from, said that the assailants had stopped the travelers at a fake checkpoint.
item.dc:creator: By YASIR GHAZI

item.title: China Seen in Push to Gain Technology Insights
item.description: As China seeks to become more competitive, scientists on the job in the United States are being asked to share technology data.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG and DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Workers at Suntech Power’s main subsidiary in Wuxi. The unit declared bankruptcy in March.

item.title: In Syrian Victory, Hezbollah Risks Broader Fight
item.description: Hezbollah’s role has further antagonized sectarian divisions in Syria and beyond, creating new risks for both the Syrian government and the militia even in their moment of victory.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD
item.media:description: Forces loyal to President Bashar al-Assad carried a flag on Wednesday after taking the town of Qusayr.

item.title: Bulgaria Tempers Blame for Hezbollah in Bombing
item.description: The country’s new government is trying to shift blame for an attack that killed five Israeli tourists and their Bulgarian driver from Hezbollah, the militant Lebanese Shiite movement.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW BRUNWASSER

item.title: Financial Fears Gain Credence as Unrest Shakes Turkey
item.description: While Turkey’s economy has grown swiftly over the past decade, the recent protests in Taksim Square are signaling that economic trouble could be approaching.
item.dc:creator: By LANDON THOMAS Jr.
item.media:description: On Wednesday, protesters in Istanbul clashed with the riot police, though some calm returned.

item.title: Kerry Meets With Venezuelan Foreign Minister
item.description: Secretary of State John Kerry and Foreign Minister Elías Jaua got together during an Organization of American States session in Guatemala.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN and RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD

item.title: Sgt. Robert Bales Pleads Guilty to Killing 16 Afghan Civilians
item.description: Staff Sgt. Robert Bales, the figure at the center of the worst American war crime in recent memory, admitted for the first time deliberately killing 16 Afghan civilians, most of them women and children.
item.dc:creator: By KIRK JOHNSON
item.media:description: A courtroom sketch of Staff Sgt. Robert Bales standing before the military judge, Col. Jeffery Nance, as his wife, Kari Bales, looked on. He admitted deliberately killing 16 Afghan civilians.

item.title: Nigerian Refugees Accuse Army of Excess Force
item.description: Nigerian soldiers in a broad assault against the Boko Haram insurgency are making little effort to spare the innocent, refugees say.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: The Lede: Civil Disobedience on a Turkish Game Show
item.description: While most of Turkey’s journalists were carefully avoiding mention of the protests this week, the host of one Turkish game show found a way to raise the issue not once but 70 times.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Qum Journal: In Iran, Qum Is a Required Campaign Stop
item.description: Candidates in Iran’s presidential election next week are making political pilgrimages to Qum, a Shiite Vatican, hoping to secure the support of its influential clerics.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: Protest Group Gives Turkish Official Its Demands
item.description: The group is seeking the dismissal of the governors of Istanbul, Ankara and Hatay as well as the heads of the security forces in those three cities.
item.dc:creator: By SEBNEM ARSU
item.media:description: Antigovernment protesters inside a damaged public bus being used as a barricade on Wednesday at Taksim Square in Istanbul.

item.title: The Lede: Video of Samantha Power’s 2002 Remarks on Imposing Peace on Israel Could Haunt Her, Israeli Paper Says
item.description: Remarks made more than a decade ago on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict by Samantha Power, who was named the next United States ambassador to the United Nations, were repeated by a newspaper report in Israel on Wednesday.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By CHRISTINE HAUSER and ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Therapy for Rape Victims Shows Promise
item.description: A type of group therapy designed for trauma victims has proved helpful for survivors of sexual violence in the war-torn African country, researchers report.
item.dc:creator: By DENISE GRADY

item.title: Sharif, Pakistan’s Prime Minister Again, Calls for End to Drone Strikes
item.description: Nawaz Sharif made the demand shortly after he won a parliamentary vote to lead the country for an unprecedented third time.
item.dc:creator: By DECLAN WALSH and SALMAN MASOOD
item.media:description: Nawaz Sharif was sworn in as Pakistan's new president in Islamabad on Wednesday.

item.title: India Ink: Police Continue Search for Suspects in American Tourist Gang-Rape
item.description: None of the suspects have been arrested so far, police said Wednesday morning.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: Policemen keeping a check on vehicles in Manali, Himachal Pradesh, on Tuesday.

item.title: Palm-Size Fossil Resets Primates’ Clock, Scientists Say
item.description: A nearly complete skeleton of a creature that weighed less than an ounce dials back the primate fossil record by eight million years, paleontologists report.
item.dc:creator: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD
item.media:description: An artist's interpretation of a tiny primate that is thought to be the earliest known ancestor of nocturnal primates living today in Southeast Asia.

item.title: In Besieged Sunni Town of Qusayr, Sunnis Are Bitter
item.description: As Hezbollah guerrillas from Lebanon and Syrian troops fought around Qusayr, many Sunnis declared the area’s social fabric had been destroyed.
item.dc:creator: By an EMPLOYEE of THE NEW YORK TIMES in SYRIA and ANNE BARNARD
item.media:description: Syrian government soldiers stood in front of a clock tower flying the national flag in the main square of the city of Qusayr on Wednesday after the army claimed it had seized total control of it and the surrounding region.

item.title: British Judge Urges Public Inquiry Into Litvinenko Death
item.description: A public investigation of the death of Alexander V. Litvinenko, a former K.G.B. officer poisoned in London in 2006, would be able to hear testimony in secret, the judge said.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: China to Investigate European Wines After Solar Panel Tariffs
item.description: The move followed Europe’s decision to impose preliminary tariffs of 11.8 percent on solar panels imported from China.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER

item.title: Leak Found in Tank at Fukushima Nuclear Plant
item.description: The discovery by the plant’s operator comes a day after an admission that radioactive particles had been found in water flowing into the stricken plant.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER
